I got this in October 2014, and only got round to playing it in February 2015. However, it did not disappoint!

This game is like Splendor in reverse. Instead of taking chips to buy cards and get points, you take cards to buy chips and get points!

This is old, but is relaxing to play, reasonably strategic, and I'm a sucker for any architectural games!
They fixed chess? Well yes, but they sucked the "chess aesthetic" dry...
Buy this for the brilliant rulebook - the solitaire game itself isn't worth it, though I quite like the design.

Variable battle setups, asymmetrical armies, cardplay, balanced luck... AWESOMENESS!!! With all that, this game couldn't have failed, and it certainly didn't!

I hope to get more plays out of this (due mainly to the cost). However, it certainly did not disappoint. MUAHHAHH!!

comment:
This game is really deep, and quite unlike the game it's normally compared to: chess. Yet, although patterns are very important in this game, there is still a much deeper degree of straight up move by move reasoning.

The thing that makes Go so good is it's elegance, and it's natural focus on personal improvement as opposed to simply playing to win. This is, and will probably long remain, my favourite game of all time.
Without expansions, I must admit that I found it rather simple. However, I would like to give it a shot with some more experienced players.

comment:
I have played this game a lot. With the right group, it becomes an overly-deep analysis of people, their reactions, voting patterns. This gives you a lot to work with, even without the in-built expansion.

As of yet, I prefer the base game to the expansion, Avalon, or any other rules twist. Personally, I think Avalon turns the game from the fun of Werewolf social deduction to the dryness of Poker.

I for one highly recommend this game, and look forward to many more plays.
